A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The centralizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $Z_{S}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in S\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Centralizer to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Centralizer involves elements of a group $G$ that commute with every element of a subset $S$ of $G$. Specifically, the centralizer $Z_S$ is defined as the set of all elements $x$ in $G$ such that $xs = sx$ for every $s$ in $S$. This definition inherently uses the idea of commutation (i.e., the property that two elements multiply to the same product regardless of the order of multiplication), which is directly related to the Commutative Law.

However, the Commutative Law as a general concept states that a binary operation on a set is commutative if the operation yields the same result regardless of the order of the operands across the entire set. In contrast, the definition of a Centralizer does not require the entire group $G$ to be commutative; it only requires that certain elements of $G$ commute with the elements of the subset $S$.

Thus, while the concept of commutation (related to the Commutative Law) is used in defining the Centralizer, the full Commutative Law itself (applying universally across all elements of a set) is not necessary for the definition of a Centralizer to make sense. The Centralizer focuses on specific relations of commutation between a subset and other elements, not on a universal commutative property across all elements of the group.
